text: that was kind of the genesis of this
idea could I you know could I break
through these barriers by actually
writing about my neighbors from inside
their own homes about half the people
that I approached said yes they work
with me and then you know a number of
those eventually I did kind of pop the
question could I stay over and write
about you know a full 24 hours of your
life from inside your own home in the
year 2000 there was tragedy on my street
down the street from me
was family husband and wife they were
both physicians and their two children a
boy 11 and a girl 12 and one night the
husband came home and he shot and killed
his wife and then took his own life
the kids ran screaming into the night
what struck me about this whole calamity
besides the tragedy of it was it didn't
seem that very much in my stream had
changed in effect this whole family had
vanished overnight I didn't know this
family well and then in asking around I
found that very few people on the street
knew them well in fact people didn't
seem to know each other beyond a
superficial level I did read the
literature the studies that showed that
what I was experiencing on my street was
you know widespread but I just didn't
want to write about the phenomenon as a
trend I really personally felt isolated
and wanted to see if I could connect
with my neighbors at some point the the
memory of childhood sleepovers came to
me you know I remembered that experience
as a kid of staying over at a friend's
house and the part I liked the most was
not actually the sleeping over but it
was waking up the next morning and
coming down to breakfast because
suddenly those other strangers in that
house like my friend's mom or my friends
older sister suddenly we become real
people and then the next time I'd I'd go
visit my friend at that house they
didn't feel like strangers after about
two and a half three years I pretty much
had what I thought was my story and had
a draft you know the New York Times what
are the chances of getting an op-ed
published there you know cold I didn't
know anybody so I polished up the piece
a little more and I hit Send and didn't
really didn't think much else about it
and then two days later I come home I
got I picked my son up from high school
and I come home I go up to my study I
log onto my email and there's this email
from the New York Times and I opened it
up and there was this short email that
said you know thanks for giving us the
opportunity to read your essay actually
we'd be delighted to publish it and then
about a week later the piece appears it
was just a very emotional experience for
me after all these years of working on
the subject to see that you know not
only had the times editor's seen
something Universal in it but in fact it
was being borne out in these readers
comments that were coming in from all
over
I felt off sudden there was this huge
neighborhood of people around the world
who were responding to the very same
thing that I had been struggling to
write about
